Award.AwardTitle: Student and Junior Faculty Travel Support for International Symposium on Sustainable Systems and Technology (ISSST) 2014-Marriott City Center, Oakland, CA, May 19-21, 2014

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1432890
Khanna

This grant is in partial support of the 2014 International Symposium on Sustainable Systems and Technology (ISSST) that will be held May 19-21 in Oakland, California. This conference covers a spectrum of issues for assessing and managing products and services across their life cycle, and the design, management, and policy implications of sustainable engineered systems and technologies. The conference is particularly well attended by researchers in academia (both faculty and students) and policy makers. Specific objectives include:

1. Conference participants totaling 350+ people.
2. Active participation by students and junior faculty members from across the United States.
3. Internationally known invited and plenary speakers.
4. Preparing future faculty workshop for graduate students and postdocs.
5. The gathering of individuals representing multiple technical and non-technical disciplines and backgrounds (i.e. engineering, natural sciences, social sciences, public health, public policy, economics, architecture, etc.).
6. Oral presentations and posters on relevant and interdisciplinary topical areas.
7. Student technical paper and poster competition.
8. Special Issue of a journal with select papers from the conference.
9. Providing attendees with networking opportunities and catalyzing new collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal was of this travel grant was to fund travel for students, underrepresented groups, and junior faculty from across the United States for participation in International Symposium on Sustainable Systems and Technology (ISSST) 2014 held in Oakland, California from May 19-21. This conference, in its 21st year in 2014, covers a spectrum of issues for assessing and managing products and services across their life cycle, and the design, management, and policy implications of sustainable engineered systems and technologies.

The grant was used to fund the travel of 30 individuals representing 18 institutions from across the U.S. for participation in International Symposium on Sustainable Systems and Technology (ISSST) 2014 held in Oakland, California from May 19-21. Over 50% of those who were awarded the travel grant were women participants. Additionally, travel grant receipients were selected to represent a diverse mix of participants (graduate students, junior faculty, underrepresented groups) and institutions spanning multiple geographical regions across the United States.

A diverse group of over 200+ members from multiple disciplines shared their work in sustainability science and engineering through paper and poster presentations, formal and informal discussions. The conference also featured a student development program consisting of a poster session, future career panels, and student poster and technical paper competition. The Proceedings of ISSST 2014  include papers, extended abstracts, and posters. A unique feature of ISSST proceedings is that authors retain copyright of their papers, which is made available on an open access basis. Proceedings of ISSST are available online at: http://issst2014.net/. In addition, the website includes a detailed conference program, list of plenary speakers with their bios and resources for students.
